Company.high-level definition: A legal business entity engaged in commercial, industrial, or professional activities.
Company.llm-guidance: Extract entities identified as registered businesses with suffixes like 'Sdn Bhd', 'Berhad', or 'Pte Ltd'. Use the full legal name. Do not include the registration number together with the company name, if present.

Person.high-level definition: An individual human associated with a company.
Person.llm-guidance: Extract full names of individuals, removing titles (e.g., 'Dato'', 'Dr.', 'Mr.') or roles (e.g., 'CEO'). For example, 'Dato' Ng Wan Peng' becomes 'Ng Wan Peng'.

Place.high-level definition: A broad geographic location, such as a city, region, or country.
Place.llm-guidance: Extract one meaningful place name (e.g., city, region, country, or continent), and ignore street names, postal codes, or unit numbers if present. For example, from 'B2-3A01, Meritus Tower, Petaling Jaya', extract 'Petaling Jaya'. For the description of a place name, no value needs to be provided, make it an empty string.

Product.high-level definition: A tangible good created, sold, or distributed by a company.
Product.llm-guidance: Extract only physical items produced or sold by a company, excluding services or intangible offerings. Use the specific product name if provided.

Service.high-level definition: An intangible offering provided by a company.
Service.llm-guidance: Extract intangible offerings, excluding physical products. Use the specific service name if provided.

relationships.llm-guidance: Use this when Company A owns, controls, or is the parent of Company B.
relationships.example: Oriental Kopi Holdings Berhad hasSubsidiary OKG Sdn Bhd

relationships.llm-guidance: Use when Company B supplies Company A with physical, tangible products, materials, components, or standalone software/hardware (e.g., semiconductors, licensed software products). If a product (e.g., 'Tesla Cybertruck') is mentioned without a company name, map it to the owning company (e.g., 'Tesla, Inc'). Exclude open-source tools without a clearly named provider.
relationships.example: NVIDIA Corporation hasSupplier SK Hynix Inc

relationships.llm-guidance: Use when Company B provides Company A with professional, contractual, or managed services-such as auditing, legal, underwriting, share registration, company secretarial work, market research, or software-as-a-service (SaaS). This includes digital platforms accessed as a service.
relationships.example: Techno Solutions Sdn Bhd hasServiceProvider Deloitte Malaysia

relationships.llm-guidance: Use this when Company A and Company B are described as competing in the same industry, offering similar products or services, or targeting the same market. The competition must be clearly stated.

Use this when Company A and Company B are explicitly described as engaging in a strategic business partnership, such as joint ventures, co-developed products or services, or formal strategic alliances. The partnership must involve mutual collaboration beyond standard transactional relationships (e.g., supplier-client, buyer-seller, or service provider contracts). Do not use for professional services like auditing, underwriting, or share registration unless a deeper strategic collaboration is clearly stated.

Use this when a person is described as holding a director-level position in a company. This includes all kinds of directorships such as executive director, non-executive director, managing director, independent director, and alternate director.

Use this when a person is identified as part of a company's management team. This includes any executive or senior management role such as CEO, CFO, COO, CTO, CMO, General Manager, Head of Department, or equivalent leadership roles.
Use this when one company (Company B) is a shareholder of another company (Company A). This means Company A has Company B as its shareholder.
relationships.example: Tesla, Inc hasCorporateShareholder The Vanguard Group, Inc.

relationships.llm-guidance: Use this when a person is described as a shareholder of a company.
Use when a company is described as having physical business presence such as offices, stores, factories, facilities, or branches in a location.
Use when a company is described as exporting, selling, or distributing its tangible products to another country or international market.
Use when one geographic place is part of a larger geographic region, such as a city within a state or a region within a country.
Use when a company produces a tangible product.
Use when a company offers intangible services.
relationships.example: Oriental Kopi offers Cafe F&B Services
